revision.comment: /* Operational service */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: tranfered → transferred, September of 2016 → September 2016 using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]

nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship status=In active service, as of 2015 |Ship notes= |Ship badge=*On a Field Black, an arm and a hand in a cresset of fire all Proper *[[File:Daring Crest.jpg|100px]] }} web|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/News-and-Events/Latest-News/2013/October/11/131011-HMS-Daring-leaves-Sydney|title=HMS Daring leaves Sydney after spectacular week of celebrations|publisher=Royal Navy|accessdate=2013-10-13}}{{cite journal|title=For Queen and Country|journal=Navy News |issue=July 2012|page=Page 8|quote="One hundred or so miles west of the largest city of Abidjan lies the fishing port of Sassandra, too small to accommodate 8,500-tonnes of Type 45."}}{{cite news|title=HMS Duncan joins US Carrier on strike operations against ISIL|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/news-and-latest-activity/news/2015/july/07/150707-duncan-joins-us-carrier-on-operations|accessdate=9 July 2015|journal=Navy News|publisher=Royal Navy|date=7 July 2015 |quote="As well as supporting the international effort against the ISIL fundamentalists – the 8,500-tonne warship has also joined the wider security mission in the region."}} |Ship length={{convert|152.4|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|21.2|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|7.4|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draft= |Ship power=*2 × [[Rolls-Royce WR-21]] [[gas turbine]]s, {{convert|21.5|MW|shp|abbr=on|lk=on}} each *2 × [[Wärtsilä]] 12V200 diesel generators, {{convert|2|MW|shp|abbr=on}} each{{cite web|url=http://www.wartsila.com/fi/references/HMS-Daring |title=HMS Daring |publisher=Wärtsilä|accessdate=2011-08-01}} |Ship propulsion=*2 shafts [[Combined diesel-electric and gas#Integrated electric propulsion|integrated electric propulsion]] with *2 × [[Converteam]] [[electric motor]]s, {{convert|20|MW|shp|abbr=on}} each |Ship speed=In excess of {{convert|30|kn|abbr=on|lk=in}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scribd.com/doc/183216219/HMS-Daring-Type-45-facts-by-Royal-Navy-pdf|title=HMS Daring - Type 45 facts by Royal Navy.pdf|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} |Ship range=In excess of {{convert|7000|nmi|km|lk=in|-3}} at {{convert|18|kn|km/h|abbr=on}} |Ship complement=191{{cite web | title=A Global Force 2012/13 | url=http://www.newsdeskmedia.com/files/Global-Force-2013.pdf | format=pdf | author=Royal Navy | publisher=Newsdesk Media | isbn=978-1-906940-75-1 | date=11 July 2013 }} Complement as of 24 April 2013 (accommodation for up to 235) |Ship sensors=*[[SAMPSON]] multi-function air tracking radar (Type 1045) *[[S1850M]] 3-D air surveillance radar (Type 1046) *Raytheon [[Navigation#Integrated bridge systems|Integrated Bridge and Navigation System]] *2 × Raytheon [[AHRS]] INS
(MINS 2) *2 × Raytheon [[I band|I-band]] Radar
(Type 1047) *1 × Raytheon [[E band (NATO)|E]]/[[F band (NATO)|F-band]] Radar
(Type 1048){{cite web|url=http://www.raytheon.co.uk/news_room/news/press_release_08032006.pdf|format=PDF|title=Raytheon Press Release|date=2006-03-08|accessdate=2008-01-31}} * [[Ultra Electronics]] Series 2500 Electro-Optical Gun Control System (EOGCS){{cite web|url=http://articles.janes.com/articles/Janes-Electro-Optic-Systems/Ultra-Electronics-Series-2500-electro-optic-tracking-and-fire-control-system-United-Kingdom.html|title=Jane's Electro-Optic Systems|date=2010-10-28|accessdate=2011-08-21}} * [[Ultra Electronics]] SML Technologies radar tracking system * [[Ultra Electronics]]/[[EDO Corporation|EDO]] MFS-7000 sonar |Ship EW=* UAT Mod 2.0 (2.1 planned){{cite news | url=http://www.mod.uk/NR/rdonlyres/3624A3FC-1A13-42AE-B5C6-CF8F730807C3/0/desider_52_Sept2012InternetU.pdf | page=18 | title=Fleet to get the latest in electronic surveillance | date=September 2012 | newspaper=DESider | publisher=Ministry of Defence}} * AN/SSQ-130 Ship Signal Exploitation Equipment (SSEE) Increment F cryptologic exploitation system {{cite news | url=http://www.janes.com/article/40127/uk-to-buy-shaman-cesm-for-seaseeker-sigint-programme | title=UK to buy Shaman CESM for Seaseeker SIGINT programme | date=29 June 2014 | publisher=IHS Janes Defense}} * [[Seagnat]] * [[Naval Decoy IDS300]] * [[SSTD|Surface Ship Torpedo Defence]] |Ship armament={{Type 45 weapon fit}} |Ship armour= |Ship aircraft= *1–2 × [[AgustaWestland AW159|Lynx Wildcat]], armed with: **4 × anti ship missiles, ''or'' **2 × anti submarine torpedoes *''or'' *1 × [[AgustaWestland AW101|Westland Merlin]],{{cite web|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/server/show/nav.2227 |title=Air Defence Destroyer (T45) |publisher=Royal Navy |accessdate=2007-11-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031074413/http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/server/show/nav.2227 |archivedate=31 October 2007 }} armed with: **4 × anti-submarine torpedoes |Ship aircraft facilities=* Large flight deck * Enclosed [[hangar]] |Ship notes= }} |} '''HMS ''Daring''''' is the lead ship of the [[Type 45 destroyer|Type 45]] or ''Daring''-class [[Anti-aircraft warfare|air-defence]] [[destroyer]]s built for the [[Royal Navy]], and the seventh ship to hold that name. She was launched in 2006 on the Clyde and conducted contractor's sea trials during 2007 and 2008. She was handed over to the Royal Navy in December 2008, entered her base port of Portsmouth for the first time in January 2009 and was formally commissioned on 23 July 2009. As the lead ship of the first destroyer class built for the Royal Navy since the [[Type 42 destroyer|Type 42]] in the 1970s, she has attracted significant media and public attention. Her name, crest and motto are a reference to the Roman youth [[Gaius Mucius Scaevola]], famed for his bravery.{{cite web |url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/The-Fleet/Ships/Destroyers/Type-45-Destroyers/HMS-Daring |title=HMS Daring |publisher=Royal Navy |accessdate=2012-09-15}} ==Construction== ''Daring''{{'}}s construction began at the [[BAE Systems Naval Ships]] yard (now [[BAE Systems Surface Ships]]) at [[Scotstoun]] on the [[River Clyde]] in March 2003.{{cite web |url=http://www.clydesite.co.uk/clydebuilt/viewship.asp?id=21075 |title=Shipping News - Yard 1061. |publisher=Clyde shipyard |accessdate=2009-01-31}} The ship was launched at 14.21 GMT on 1 February 2006. HRH [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex|The Countess of Wessex]] was the ship's [[Ship naming and launching|sponsor]] at her launch.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/4667132.stm |title=Thousands cheer on warship launch |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2007-07-19 | date=2006-02-01}} On 16 November 2006, the Countess of Wessex brought ''Daring'' to life on her first official visit. On 17 November 2006, the countess switched on the ship's diesel generators, part of the 'powering up' ceremony.{{cite web |url=http://www.royal-navy.mod.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.7268 |title=''Daring'' powered up for first time |publisher=Royal Navy |accessdate=2007-07-19}} ==Sea trials== On 18 July 2007 ''Daring'' sailed on the first set of sea trials (Stage 1.1),{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/glasgow_and_west/6904026.stm |title=HMS ''Daring'' sets sail for trials |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2007-07-19 | date=2007-07-18}} successfully completing them 4 weeks later on 14 August 2007.{{cite news |url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.10007 | title=New destroyer boosts Navy |publisher=Royal Navy |accessdate=2007-08-14 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070927000810/http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.10007 |archivedate = 2007-09-27}} As she is the first in the class some structural areas needed to be tested, including the loads that the main [[4.5 inch Mark 8 naval gun]] puts on the ship.{{cite web |url=http://www.royal-navy.mod.uk/server/show/ConWebDoc.9826 |title=Navys latest destroyer takes to the High Seas |publisher=Royal Navy |date=2007-07-19 |accessdate=2007-07-24}} During these trials, ''Daring'' reached her design speed of {{convert|29|kn|km/h|0}} in 70 seconds and achieved a speed of {{convert|31.5|kn|km/h|0}} in 120 seconds.{{cite news|url=http://www.theherald.co.uk/news/news/display.var.1617705.0.0.php|first=Alan|last=MacDermid|title=''Daring'' is mean, green and built for speed|work=The Herald|date=2007-08-15|accessdate=2007-08-15}} She sailed for Stage 1.2 on 30 March 2008 and returned on 2 May. Stage 1.2 included trials on the Long Range Radar and navigation system, medium calibre gun blast trials, weapon alignment tests and endurance tests.{{cite web |url=http://www.technologynewsdaily.com/node/9570 |title=Destroyer HMS ''Daring'', Second Stage Sea Trials|publisher=TechNEWS|date=2008-04-05 |accessdate=2008-05-02}} Stage 1.3 trials were conducted between 26 August{{cite web|url=http://jackspeak.royalnavy.mod.uk/author/alastair-bancroft/|title=Jack Speak blogs - Al Bancroft|publisher=[[Royal Navy]]|accessdate=2008-09-26}} and 22 September 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.blogs.mod.uk/defence_news/2008/week39/index.html#entry-55790862|title=Defence News, 22 September 2008 - 28 September 2008|publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)]]|accessdate=2008-09-26}} and emphasis was placed on testing the full range of communications equipment. The ship's company used the opportunity to conduct familiarisation and training activities in preparation for the transfer of the vessel to the Royal Navy in December 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/DefenceNews/EquipmentAndLogistics/DaringReadyToTakeToTheWaves.htm|title=''Daring Ready To Take To The Waves'', Defence News article|publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)]]|accessdate=2008-09-26}} Stage 2 trials took place in 2009, once the ship had been handed over to the Royal Navy.{{cite web |url=http://www.fleet-support.co.uk/News/T45-arrival.htm |title=Gearing Up for T45s Arrival|publisher=FSL|date=2007-09-24 |accessdate=2008-05-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/DefenceNews/EquipmentAndLogistics/DaringhandedtoMOD.htm|title=''Daring'' handed to MOD|date=2008-12-10|publisher=MoD}} HMS ''Daring'' arrived in her home port of Portsmouth on 28 January 2009{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/hampshire/7852111.stm |title=BBC coverage of HMS Daring's homecoming |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2009-01-28 | date=2009-01-28}} to large crowds along the seafront.{{cite news |url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/hmsdaringlive |title=HMS ''Daring'' Live Blog |publisher=The News, Portsmouth |accessdate=2009-01-26}} She was given the honour of a flypast to coincide with her passing of the [[Round Tower (Portsmouth)|Round Tower]], just outside Portsmouth.{{cite news |url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/hmsdaring/The-dawn-of-Daring.4914917.jp |title=The dawn of ''Daring'' |publisher=The News, Portsmouth |accessdate=2009-01-26}} ==Operational service== ''Daring'' was formally commissioned on 23 July 2009 with [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex|The Countess of Wessex]] inspecting an honour guard on the quayside, and reception. The commissioning cake was cut by the wife of the commanding officer and Able Seaman Daniel Small, who was the youngest member of the ship’s company. ''Daring'' was declared officially "in service" one year later, on 31 July 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/news-and-events/rn-live/all-news/hms-daring-sails-into-service/*/changeNav/6568|title=HMS ''Daring'' Sails Into Service |publisher=Royal Navy Website|date=2010-07-31|accessdate=2010-09-23}} ''Daring'' fired her first Sea Viper missile in May 2011 during a test launch in the Outer Hebrides, after years of trials.{{cite news |url=http://www.navynews.co.uk/news/1185-daring-finally-shows-her-bite.aspx |title=Daring finally shows her bite |date=17 May 2011 |newspaper=Navy News |accessdate=18 May 2011}} During the same year she was equipped with two Phalanx CIWS mounted on either side of the superstructure.[http://www.naval-technology.com/news/news122572.html Babcock to Test Phalanx 1B CIWS on HMS Daring], naval-technology.com, 24 June 2011 On 6 January 2012, the Royal Navy announced that ''Daring'' would leave Portsmouth on 11 January 2012 to undertake her first mission, a deployment to the [[Persian Gulf]]. ''Daring'' travelled through the Suez Canal on 2 February 2012, then continued on to the Persian Gulf, relieving the [[Type 23 frigate]] {{HMS|Argyll|F231|6}} that was on station there.{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/defence/8997956/Royal-Navy-sends-its-mighiest-ship-to-take-on-the-Iranian-show-of-force-in-the-Gulf.html |title=Royal Navy sends its mightiest ship to take on the Iranian show of force in the Gulf |date=6 January 2012 |newspaper=The Telegraph UK |accessdate=6 January 2012 |location=London |first=Thomas |last=Harding}}{{cite web|url=http://navynews.co.uk/archive/news/item/3521|title=Navy News - Reporting from the Fleet|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} In February 2012, as part of the Persian Gulf deployment, ''Daring'' joined Operation Scimitar Anzac, an anti-piracy operation in the [[Red Sea]] and the [[Gulf of Aden]]. This international operation included the [[Royal Fleet Auxiliary]] {{ship|RFA|Wave Knight|A389|6}}, the [[Royal Australian Navy]] frigate {{HMAS|Parramatta|FFH 154|6}}, and the [[Pakistan Navy]]'s [[HMS Amazon (F169)|PNS ''Babur'']]. ''Daring'' acted as the command ship for all the vessels.{{cite web|url=http://navynews.co.uk/archive/news/item/3751|title=Navy News - Reporting from the Fleet|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} During operation in the Persian Gulf and [[North Arabian Sea]], ''Daring'' operated with the U.S. Navy's [[Carrier Strike Group One]] and [[Carrier Strike Group Nine]].{{cite web | title= Daring enjoys ‘truly amazing’ experience working with American carriers | url= http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/News-and-Events/Latest-News/2012/March/20/120320-Daring-Carriers | work= News & Events | publisher= [[Royal Navy]] | date= March 20, 2012 | accessdate=2012-03-23}} In September 2013, ''Daring'' transited the [[Panama Canal]] on deployment to the [[Pacific Ocean]]. She made port visits to the US [[Naval Base San Diego]],{{cite web|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/News-and-Events/Latest-News/2013/May/28/130528-Daring-deploys|title=HMS Daring goes on global deployment - Royal Navy|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} [[Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam]],{{cite web|url=http://www.naval.com.br/blog/2013/07/10/hms-daring-visita-pearl-harbor/#axzz2YrC4TVN7|title=HMS ‘Daring’ visita Pearl Harbor|first=Alexandre|last=Galante|date=10 July 2013|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} and the [[Marshall Islands]].{{cite web|url=https://navynews.co.uk/archive/news/item/8905|title=Navy News - Reporting from the Fleet|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} While in the Pacific, ''Daring'' took part in the [[Royal Australian Navy]]'s [[International Fleet Review 2013]] at [[Sydney]], [[Australia]] and also participated in the 2013 [[Five Power Defence Arrangements]] exercise, Bersama Lima.{{cite web|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/News-and-Events/Latest-News/2013/October/31/131031-Daring-arrives-in-Singapore|title=Daring arrives in Singapore ahead of five nations exercise - Royal Navy|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} During Bersama Lima, ''Daring'' was urgently dispatched to the [[Philippines]] as part of the British government's [[humanitarian response to Typhoon Haiyan]].{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-24906526 | work=BBC News | title=UK to send ship to help Philippines, David Cameron announces | date=11 November 2013}} Before her return to the United Kingdom, ''Daring'' made port visits in Japan,{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/world-location-news/hms-daring-bound-for-japan|title=HMS Daring visits Japan - News articles - GOV.UK|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} South Korea, China, Vietnam,{{cite web|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/News-and-Events/Latest-News/2013/December/19/131219-Daring-visits-Vietnam|title=HMS Daring visits Vietnam - Royal Navy|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} Thailand and Malaysia.{{cite web|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/News-and-Events/Latest-News/2014/January/10/140110-Warship-Visits-Thailand|title=HMS Daring pays a visit to Thailand - Royal Navy|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}} In September 2016 ''Daring'' was transferred to the Persian Gulf to assist in [[Operation Inherent Resolve]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.rt.com/uk/357554-daring-destroyer-isis-failures/|title=UK sends destroyer to fight ISIS in Persian Gulf, despite its previous warm water failures|language=en-EN|access-date=2016-08-29}} ==Characteristics== {{Main article|Type 45 destroyer#Characteristics}} ==Commanding Officers== *2008-2009: Captain Paul Bennett RN *2009-2011: Captain Paul McAlpine RN *2011-2012: Captain Guy Robinson RN *2012–2014: Commander Angus Essenhigh RN *2014–Present: Commander Philip Dennis RN ==Affiliations== ===Ship's sponsor=== *HRH [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex|The Countess of Wessex]] ===Official affiliations=== *[[City of Birmingham]]{{cite web |url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/our-organisation/the-fighting-arms/surface-fleet/destroyers/hms-daring/daring-info|title=HMS ''Daring'' - Affiliations |publisher=Royal Navy |accessdate=2015-10-05}} * Warwickshire District [[Sea Cadets]] *[[Guernsey]] *[[The Royal Dragoon Guards]] *[[No. 11 Squadron RAF]] *[[HMS Forward (shore establishment 1984)|HMS ''Forward'']] (Birmingham Royal Naval Reserve) *The ''Daring'' Association *[[King Edward's School, Birmingham]] *[http://www.knowleseascouts.org.uk 4th Knowle Sea Scout Group] *[[Worshipful Company of Carpenters]] (A City of London Livery Company){{cite web |url=http://www.thecarpenterscompany.co.uk/pages/charities/military_affiliations/default.aspx |title=Military links |publisher=Carpenter's Company |accessdate=2009-01-31}} *[[Birmingham University]] [[University Royal Naval Unit|Royal Naval Unit]] *The D-Boats Association *Midland Naval Officers Association *''Daring'' Class Yachts{{cite web|url=http://www.daring.org.uk/content/royal_navy.htm|accessdate=2008-02-28|title=Affiliation with the Royal Navy's new Destroyer Class}} ===Other=== While not officially affiliated with the football club [[Aston Villa F.C.]], the ship has close ties with the team. The chairman of the Birmingham-based club, [[Randy Lerner]], donated a painting to the ship that depicts a maritime battle played within [[Villa Park]], the home stadium of the club. Members of the ship's company provided a [[guard of honour]] before a game against [[Middlesbrough F.C.]] on the [[Remembrance Sunday]] weekend.{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.net/news/top-stories/2009/01/28/villa-chairman-randy-lerner-is-number-one-fan-of-hms-daring-97319-22799601/ |title=Villa chairman Randy Lerner is number one fan of HMS ''Daring'' |last=Richards |first=Andy |date=2009-01-29 |publisher=Birmingham Mail |accessdate=2009-01-29}} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=N}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|HMS Daring (D32)}} *[http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/our-organisation/the-fighting-arms/surface-fleet/destroyers/hms-daring Royal Navy HMS ''Daring''] (royalnavy.mod.uk) *[http://www.axfordsabode.org.uk/daridet.htm ''Daring'' association website] (axfordsabode.org.uk) {{Type 45 destroyer}} {{Royal Navy ships}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} {{Use British English|date=March 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Daring (D32)}} [[Category:Type 45 destroyers]] [[Category:Clyde-built ships]] [[Category:2006 ships]] [[Category:Active destroyers of the United Kingdom]]
